TEXT.English: Thick curls of smoke floated up from the camp's remains. Whatever army had camped there was gone now.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It's like chasing the wind," Lucian said in frustration, "what is the point of a mercenary army if you can never catch up with them long enough to hire them?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Is it possible they were defeated here; I heard they were involved in the war between the sandmen and the cabal."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric considered Riuros's suggestion, "Maybe. There must be survivors from one side or the other, send out the scouts and see if they can track some down. I want to talk to any Hippus they find, so make sure they aren't attacked."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]That last instruction was for Lucian; the Doviello scouts were excellent trackers but horrible diplomats.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A few days later they had three different reports from the scouts. One reported Hippus commanders in the Calabim city of Acaia gloating of their victory and the wisdom hiring them. Another reported disheveled Hippus units in the Malakim city of Bryn that spoke of a crushing loss on the plains. The last reported a significant Hippus army massed in a nearby valley, looking unbloodied and well rested.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But when they arrived at the valley the Hippus were gone, as were any signs that they had been there. The scout stared dumbfounded at the empty valley and would have been beaten for leading the army to the empty valley if Riuros didn't spot a small band of riders under the Hippus flag heading toward them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There were four riders. Tasunke was as close as the Hippus had to a king, and his three captains let him do the talking. After introductions Tasunke asked if Auric wanted to hire the Hippus.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes," Auric answered, "the capture of Torrolerial and Midgar has deepened our treasury but shortened our time. I want to hire you to go to the Finnian Fields and recover an item from the Luchuirp, a golem named Barnaxus."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"How are we to know which golem is the right one? Battle doesn't often allow for the exchange of pleasantries."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric paused, then to the surprise of Lucian and the priests he ignored Tasunke's sarcasm and returned only a thin, insincere smile.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Barnaxus has the mark of the white hand upon him. Find the golem with that mark and bring him to me to earn your reward."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That we can do." Tasunke replied, "But I will need money to finance the move of my army to the Finnian Fields. The Luchuirp aren't likely to give up their golem so easily."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric thought carefully before responding.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I will pay for every enemy you kill upon the fields. Show dedication to your task and you will be able to bring your men. Relax in valley camps and pretend to fight wars and you will get no money from me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I am agreed. We will see you on the fields." And with that Tasunke and his captains were off.

TEXT.English: "Sorry he couldn't be brought back in better shape, he put up a fight."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric ignored Tasunke's comment. He was staring reverently at the broken pieces of Barnaxus that Tasunke had laid on the meeting rooms sturdy table. Auric touched each piece carefully, as if they were religious artifacts.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian stood near the door of the chamber, seeming the least confused by Auric's actions but only because he had given up trying to understand them. Dumannios, Riuros, and Anagantios all watched Auric carefully, sensing something deeply significant in the golem's shattered parts but unable to tell what. Tasunke just waited to get paid.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The room's only other occupant was caged. Beeri Bawl, Luchuirp king, sat ignobly in an old wolf pen that Tasunke had dragged along as a special present for Auric. Beeri was the most surprised to find that Barnaxus was not only the cause of the war with the Hippus, but of so much interest to the Illian priests.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This is not a golem," Auric began, "he is not powered by gears and dwarven enchantment but by the divine breath of Mulcarn himself. This is the last piece of Mulcarn, that which was untouched by the Godslayer."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Oh yeah, that golem's a god. I got a pair of boots made out of Bhall's panties too if you're interested. They smell kinda funny but sure do keep your toes warm on a cold night."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Everyone but Auric glowered at Beeri, but he only crossed his arms and stared back at them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric placed his hands on the chest of the broken golem and began chanting. The spell started low and quiet as he repeated each incantation. To Tasunke it sounded like a lullaby, but in a language he had never heard. It wasn't harsh or chaotic like the spells he was used to hearing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As Auric continued to cast the room chilled to the point where everyone's breath could be seen. Outside of Auric's spell the rest of the sound dimmed and Beeri yelled and thrashed against the bars of his cage, but it went unnoticed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Barnaxus's chest began to glow. As everyone watched a white radiance spread along the broken pieces and then gathered in his chest before flaring in the symbol of a white hand. The flare was so bright everyone was momentarily blinded, but when they could see again the shadow of Mulcarn stood above the table.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Dumannios, Riuros, and Anagantios fell to their knees. Tasunke felt his knees wobble, as if subconsciously wanting to worship the figure before him, but he resisted.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Mulcarn wasn't there, he wasn't real. It was only a glimmer of his power like the glow of sunlight after it has passed beneath the mountains. But still there was godhood in that image. And in that moment, with Auric standing arms outstretched before the last remnant of Mulcarn's power he did look like a man ascending to heaven.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The light turned to pale mist and Auric breathed it in. His body strained against the energy that coursed through it, then faded leaving him triumphant and weary for the experience. The three priests continued praying, but did so now at Auric's feet.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Looking at Lucian Auric said, "See that the horse lord is paid well for his service."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Tasunke smiled, "and what of the dwarf I brought you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric considered Beeri closely, "He's very funny. Sell him to Perpentach, I'm sure the Momus can use another jester."

Auric touched each piece carefully, as if they were religious artifacts.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian stood near the door of the chamber, seeming the least confused by Auric's actions but only because he had given up trying to understand them. Dumannios, Riuros, and Anagantios all watched Auric carefully, sensing something deeply significant in the golem's shattered parts but unable to tell what. Tasunke just waited to get paid.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The room's only other occupant was caged. Beeri Bawl, Luchuirp king, sat ignobly in an old wolf pen that Tasunke had dragged along as a special present for Auric. Beeri was the most surprised to find that Barnaxus was not only the cause of the war with the Hippus, but of so much interest to the Illian priests.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This is not a golem," Auric began, "he is not powered by gears and dwarven enchantment but by the divine breath of Mulcarn himself. This is the last piece of Mulcarn, that which was untouched by the Godslayer."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Oh yeah, that golem's a god. I got a pair of boots made out of Bhall's panties too if you're interested. They smell kinda funny but sure do keep your toes warm on a cold night."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Everyone but Auric glowered at Beeri, but he only crossed his arms and stared back at them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric placed his hands on the chest of the broken golem and began chanting. The spell started low and quiet as he repeated each incantation. To Tasunke it sounded like a lullaby, but in a language he had never heard. It wasn't harsh or chaotic like the spells he was used to hearing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As Auric continued to cast the room chilled to the point where everyone's breath could be seen. Outside of Auric's spell the rest of the sound dimmed and Beeri yelled and thrashed against the bars of his cage, but it went unnoticed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Barnaxus's chest began to glow. As everyone watched a white radiance spread along the broken pieces and then gathered in his chest before flaring in the symbol of a white hand. The flare was so bright everyone was momentarily blinded, but when they could see again the shadow of Mulcarn stood above the table.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Dumannios, Riuros, and Anagantios fell to their knees. Tasunke felt his knees wobble, as if subconsciously wanting to worship the figure before him, but he resisted.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Mulcarn wasn't there, he wasn't real. It was only a glimmer of his power like the glow of sunlight after it has passed beneath the mountains. But still there was godhood in that image. And in that moment, with Auric standing arms outstretched before the last remnant of Mulcarn's power he did look like a man ascending to heaven.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The light turned to pale mist and Auric breathed it in. His body strained against the energy that coursed through it, then faded leaving him triumphant and weary for the experience. The three priests continued praying, but did so now at Auric's feet.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Looking at Lucian Auric said, "See that the horse lord is paid well for his service."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Tasunke smiled, "and what of the dwarf I brought you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric considered Beeri closely, "He's very funny. Sell him to Perpentach, I'm sure the Momus can use another jester."

TEXT.English: Auric spent days within his tent as the army waited. He wasn't planning or meeting with his captains, but possessed of a deep depression and sleeping. No one was able to rouse him from his tent and those that tried were met either with anger or simply ignored. The aenemic Illian warriors feared upcoming battles and the Doviello complained that there wasn't battle enough.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Until the morning Auric walked out and viewed the milling troops. He was once again a god king and at his command the army rose up and was ready to march. He spoke of their upcoming victories, of the returning God of Winter, blood enough to satiate the savage Doviello and the glory of a world once again under the hand of the Illians. And the army cheered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]This was his way, battling between inhuman passion and despair. Both emotions overwhelmed and drove him on.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Only the immortals can funnel the divine, if I mean to ascend it will be through their blood."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian followed behind Auric and his captains. The captains asked questions, and Auric answered cryptically or not at all, they advised against direct attack on the civilized lands and Auric was disgusted with them. He finally turned at looked at the trailing Lucian.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What of the Doviello, have you the courage to reclaim your place beside winter's throne?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"My men are ready," Lucian answered, "how would you like them deployed?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric smiled. "Your faith will be rewarded. We will attack into the Bannor lands, we will assault their capital and march into their largest cathedral. Within there is a holy chamber where loyal Sabathiel rests. We will enter and pull the archangel from the chamber, and then sacrifice him on the cathedral floor to power our ritual."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Illian captains' white skin paled even further; they were shocked beyond speech.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lucian replied, "When you command it, the Doviello will be ready."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric nodded and Lucian returned to his men. They grumbled at the wasted days and he promised they would have ample opportunity to fight ahead. Lucian kept his concerns to himself.

TEXT.English: Lucian loosed his men to ravage Torrolerial. The battle had been hard fought and they had earned their reward. He followed Auric into the cathedral flanked by Illian captains who cut down the remaining priests defending the building.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The walls were covered in scenes of the Bannor's battles in hell. In each Sabathiel or Capria stood protectively over the loyal soldiers. In one a single Bannor soldier stood before a closing portal with a host of demons around him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the center of cathedral was a chamber covered with the symbols of Junil. A door set with a blazing sword was the only way into the chamber and the laws to enter were inscribed on it. It claimed that the area beyond was between this world and heaven, that it was sanctified ground and that only the high priests could open or pass through the door.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric ignored the warnings and threw the door open. Lucian readied his axe; he didnt know what to expect from an archangel but his axe hadn't failed him yet.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But the chamber beyond was empty. There was only dust inside, no one had entered the chamber for years.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Has Sabathiel fled?" one of the captains asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No." Despite his frustration Auric smiled. "The priests have been lying to the people. They claim that their laws are passed down from the archangel that protected them in hell but he abandoned them long ago. But they continue to use his legend to control the Bannor. This lie has cost them their capital."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And what of our ritual?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It seems we have another debt to repay. Sabathiel is not the only archangel in Erebus-there is one within the Grigori lands as well."

TEXT.English: Midgar burned. The Grigori capital was a stark contrast to that of the Bannor. Where the Bannor had temples the Grigori have meeting halls. Where the Bannor had religious symbols the Grigori had graceful art. Most noticeably the architecture of Alexandria shared a common design of fortified buildings, flags and banners. The Grigori buildings were as dissimilar as the people who made them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But the tapestry of buildings was united by the palace at its center. There was nothing like it in the city and its beautiful black and copper parapets were a source of inspiration for all the citizens. A testament to what men could create. When he wasn't in his throne room Cassiel himself spent hours within the palace's towers, looking out over his city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]No doubt Cassiel knew we were coming. Many had fled from the city before Auric's army arrived. Lucian assumed the palace would be as empty as Sabathiel's chamber within the cathedral. Auric was becoming more despondent as they marched toward the capital, and in the past few days even the news of their victories had gone unnoticed as he was retreating more and more into the grip of depression.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But this morning he arose again reborn. And everyone scrambled to keep up with him as he marched through the capital toward the palace. Ignoring the orders to flee a few loyal craftsmen defended the palace, their love for their king overruling their fear of the invading armies. Their defense was short lived and Auric marched into the throne room.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cassiel stood in the center of the chamber. He was tall, and perfectly formed, as if a sculptor had formed the ideal man out of marble. There was no doubt that he was an archangel and in his eyes you could see the wisdom gained in his immortal life, and the weight of its burden upon him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I worried that I would need to raze every Grigori city in Erebus before I would find you." Auric said.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Leave my children be, I am the one you want."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With that Auric commanded the Illian captains forward and they bound the archangel with four massive iron manacles brought especially for the purpose. Cassiel's clothes were torn off and a team of men took each chain, two for his arms and two for his legs and pulled them taunt. Lifting Cassiel off the ground and stretching him out until he screamed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Those screams echoed through the palace halls and out into the city. There was so much torment and pain in them that everyone paused, saddened by their sound. Where Doviello soldiers brutally beat the last of the city's defenders both stopped to listen to the cries. For the first time the Doviello questioned their battle, and the dying Grigori shared tears with their leader.[PARAGRAPH:1]"There is a rescue waiting for you" Auric taunted, "A god who may be willing to accept you back in his ara. Will you trade the ideology of three ages for a chance to retain your immortal soul? Are you willing to admit that you exist only to serve the gods? How do you feel about divine intervention now that it is the only thing that can save you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cassiel didn't reply except to scream louder as his shoulders were ripped from their sockets with a dull pop. His shoulders flushed deep purple with blood and his arms rotated without restriction, only held to his body by skin and a few remaining tendons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric took out a copper dagger and held it over Cassiel's heart.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And when you die what heaven will accept you? I suspect only Agares will accept one who has so openly defied the gods."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You are a farmer's son," Cassiel replied with great strain, "a boy who loved reading and nature. This voice that drives is not you. It promises power but it will imprison you. You must give up this war or you will ruin many lives, including your own."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric ignored the warning and plunged the dagger into Cassiel's heart. The archangel's scream echoed throughout the capital. The men holding the chains continued pulling in those last few seconds until Cassiel died and then they let his body drop onto the floor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Everyone except Auric waited to see if Cassiel would be reborn, but he didn't move. Auric was finishing the ritual with the bloodied dagger. Slowly, carefully, he completed the spell by pushing the daggers blade into his right hand, cutting his flesh and allowing his blood to mix with the dead archangel.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In that moment, in a thousand different places in Erebus prophets received visions of a white dragon swallowing the world. Priests were overcome with a sense of foreboding and a cool wind blew through even the warmest areas. Auric's ascension had begun.
TEXT.French: Midgar burned. The Grigori capital was a stark contrast to that of the Bannor. Where the Bannor had temples the Grigori have meeting halls. Where the Bannor had religious symbols the Grigori had graceful art. Most noticeably the architecture of Alexandria shared a common design of fortified buildings, flags and banners. The Grigori buildings were as dissimilar as the people who made them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But the tapestry of buildings was united by the palace at its center. There was nothing like it in the city and its beautiful black and copper parapets were a source of inspiration for all the citizens. A testament to what men could create. When he wasn't in his throne room Cassiel himself spent hours within the palace's towers, looking out over his city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]No doubt Cassiel knew we were coming. Many had fled from the city before Auric's army arrived. Lucian assumed the palace would be as empty as Sabathiel's chamber within the cathedral. Auric was becoming more despondent as they marched toward the capital, and in the past few days even the news of their victories had gone unnoticed as he was retreating more and more into the grip of depression.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But this morning he arose again reborn. And everyone scrambled to keep up with him as he marched through the capital toward the palace. Ignoring the orders to flee a few loyal craftsmen defended the palace, their love for their king overruling their fear of the invading armies. Their defense was short lived and Auric marched into the throne room.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cassiel stood in the center of the chamber. He was tall, and perfectly formed, as if a sculptor had formed the ideal man out of marble. There was no doubt that he was an archangel and in his eyes you could see the wisdom gained in his immortal life, and the weight of its burden upon him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I worried that I would need to raze every Grigori city in Erebus before I would find you." Auric said.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Leave my children be, I am the one you want."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With that Auric commanded the Illian captains forward and they bound the archangel with four massive iron manacles brought especially for the purpose. Cassiel's clothes were torn off and a team of men took each chain, two for his arms and two for his legs and pulled them taunt. Lifting Cassiel off the ground and stretching him out until he screamed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Those screams echoed through the palace halls and out into the city. There was so much torment and pain in them that everyone paused, saddened by their sound. Where Doviello soldiers brutally beat the last of the city's defenders both stopped to listen to the cries. For the first time the Doviello questioned their battle, and the dying Grigori shared tears with their leader.[PARAGRAPH:1]"There is a rescue waiting for you" Auric taunted, "A god who may be willing to accept you back in his ara. Will you trade the ideology of three ages for a chance to retain your immortal soul? Are you willing to admit that you exist only to serve the gods? How do you feel about divine intervention now that it is the only thing that can save you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cassiel didn't reply except to scream louder as his shoulders were ripped from their sockets with a dull pop. His shoulders flushed deep purple with blood and his arms rotated without restriction, only held to his body by skin and a few remaining tendons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric took out a copper dagger and held it over Cassiel's heart.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And when you die what heaven will accept you? I suspect only Agares will accept one who has so openly defied the gods."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You are a farmer's son," Cassiel replied with great strain, "a boy who loved reading and nature. This voice that drives is not you. It promises power but it will imprison you. You must give up this war or you will ruin many lives, including your own."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Auric ignored the warning and plunged the dagger into Cassiel's heart. The archangel's scream echoed throughout the capital. The men holding the chains continued pulling in those last few seconds until Cassiel died and then they let his body drop onto the floor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Everyone except Auric waited to see if Cassiel would be reborn, but he didn't move. Auric was finishing the ritual with the bloodied dagger. Slowly, carefully, he completed the spell by pushing the daggers blade into his right hand, cutting his flesh and allowing his blood to mix with the dead archangel.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In that moment, in a thousand different places in Erebus prophets received visions of a white dragon swallowing the world. Priests were overcome with a sense of foreboding and a cool wind blew through even the warmest areas. Auric's ascension had begun.

TEXT.English: "Welcome, Decius. We have been expecting you. My name is Confessor Wallon. It is Sabathiel's will that I accompany you. The Diviners' have great fears about the safety of our southwest settlements, indeed, of the whole empire if the threat growing there spreads. We should set out there at once."

Wir sollten uns sofort dorthin begeben."

TEXT.English: Description: The Bannor Empire is a nation born of tragedy, struggle, and endless war. A people sustained by piety, honor, and unyielding discipline. An uncompromising people gathers many enemies, but the Bannor have no shortage of heroes. Such as Decius, a man brave, loyal, and ever steadfast. But an uncompromising man gains many enemies as well. In the Fall of Cuantine, Decius is called upon to face a threat that grows near the heart of the Empire, in the seemingly peaceful Adian Fields...[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Special Rules: Rosier must survive.

Ein Volk, das von Frömmigkeit, Ehre und unbeugsamer Disziplin zusammengehalten wird. Ein unnachgiebiges Volk macht sich zwar viele Feinde, aber die Bannor haben keinen Mangel an Helden. Wie etwa Decius, ein tapferer, loyaler und allzeit unerschütterlicher Mann. Aber ein unnachgiebiger Mann macht sich ebenfalls viele Feinde. In "Der Untergang von Cuantine" ist Decius aufgefordert, einer Bedrohung gegenüber zu treten, das nahe des Herzens des Reiches wächst, in den scheinbar friedvollen Adian-Feldern...[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Besondere Regeln: Rosier muss überleben.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Belohnung: Der erfolgreiche Abschluss dieses Szenarios gewährt Zugang zum Szenario "In die Wüste".

TEXT.English: Decius wipes the goblin blood from his sword and without pause begins the next task-razing the fort the goblins were using to launch attacks at the Bannor outpost. He is soon interrupted by a messenger. "Decius Achare, you are requested by the Lady Commanders." Decius nods and sets his men to tearing down the goblin fortifications.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Decius, I am sending you back to Torrolerial."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes milady. May I speak freely?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Of course."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Why send a man of action back to the capital? This seems a demotion to me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria smiles. "No, it is not a demotion nor is it my decision. The Diviner claims it is of great importance that you do so, or all of the Empire is imperiled. So go at once and report to your father." Decius turned to gather supplies, and was riding homeward within the hour.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius entered the meeting hall of House Achare's stronghold. "I have come, Lord Commander, though I know not why. Lady Capria had good use of me in the front."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lord Samatheon replied, "We are off the field, my son, you can drop my title. Your name has gained some renown, and I would grant you your command. Though you are right to suspect that I would leave you to Lady Capria until the completion of her campaign if I could. While the Diviners are as forthcoming as usual, they must be heeded, and they have expressed grave concerns about supernatural threats in this region. Since your brother has taken his command south to reinforce the Labuscrum, I need a commander I can trust for House Achares legions. I place you in command of our expeditionary force; unfortunately you will be need an 'advisor.'"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I thank you for your trust, father, I shall do you proud."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"As the priests say, first to your god, then to your king, then to your commander. Go therefore to the Abbey of Brigit's Light, then to the duties they have for our forces. Return home when you can, for I would like much to hear news of your travels. Dismissed."

Schon bald wurde er von einem Boten unterbrochen. "Decius Achare, die Kommandantin wünscht Euch zu sehen." Decius nickte und befahl seinen Männern die Befestigungen der Goblins niederzureißen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Decius, ich sende euch zurück nach Torolerial."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ja milady. Darf ich frei sprechen?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Natürlich."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Warum einen Mann der Tat zur Hauptstadt zurücksenden? Dies erscheint als Degradierung."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria lächelt. "Nein, es ist weder eine Degradierung noch meine Entscheidung. Der Seher sagt es ist von großer Wichtigkeit das Ihr dies tut, wenn nicht das ganze Imperium gefährdet sein soll. So gehet und meldet euch bei Eurem Vater." Daraufhin ging Decius Vorräte sammeln und war innerhalb einer Stunde auf dem Weg heimwärts.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius betrat den Besprechungssaal der Festung vom Haus Achare. "Ich bin hier, Kommandant, doch weis ich nicht wieso. Lady Capria hätte mich an der Front gebrauchen können"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lord Samatheon antwortete, "Wir sind hier unter uns, mein Sohn, Du brauchst mich nicht mit meinem Titel anzusprechen. Du hast etwas Anerkennung erlangt und ich würde Dir gern Dein Kommando geben. Aber Du hast Recht das ich Dich bis zum Ende ihrer Kampagne bei Lady Capria gelassen hätte, wenn ich könnte. Auch wenn die Seher so mitteilsam wie immer sind, so müssen sie doch erhört werden, und übernatürliche Bedrohungen in der Region machen ihnen Sorgen. Da Dein Bruder nach Süden gesendet wurde um Labscrum zu verstärken brauchte ich einen Kommandanten dem ich die Truppen des Hauses Achare anvertrauen konnte. Ich gebe Dir das Kommando unserer Expeditionstruppe; leider wirst Du einen 'Berater' benötigen."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ich danke Dir für dein Vertrauen, Vater, ich werde Dich stolz machen."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Wie die Priester immer sagen, erst zu Gott, dann zum König und dann zu Eurem Kommandanten. Geh denn zur Abtei von Brigits' Licht, dann zu den Aufgaben die sie für unsere Truppen haben. Kehre Heim wenn Du kannst, denn ich will viel von Deinen Taten hören. Wegtreten!
TEXT.Italian: Decius wipes the goblin blood from his sword and without pause begins the next task-razing the fort the goblins were using to launch attacks at the Bannor outpost. He is soon interrupted by a messenger. "Decius Achare, you are requested by the Lady Commanders." Decius nods and sets his men to tearing down the goblin fortifications.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Decius, I am sending you back to Torrolerial."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes milady. May I speak freely?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Of course."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Why send a man of action back to the capital? This seems a demotion to me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria smiles. "No, it is not a demotion nor is it my decision. The Diviner claims it is of great importance that you do so, or all of the Empire is imperiled. So go at once and report to your father." Decius turned to gather supplies, and was riding homeward within the hour.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius entered the meeting hall of House Achare's stronghold. "I have come, Lord Commander, though I know not why. Lady Capria had good use of me in the front."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Lord Samatheon replied, "We are off the field, my son, you can drop my title. Your name has gained some renown, and I would grant you your command. Though you are right to suspect that I would leave you to Lady Capria until the completion of her campaign if I could. While the Diviners are as forthcoming as usual, they must be heeded, and they have expressed grave concerns about supernatural threats in this region. Since your brother has taken his command south to reinforce the Labuscrum, I need a commander I can trust for House Achares legions. I place you in command of our expeditionary force; unfortunately you will be need an 'advisor.'"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I thank you for your trust, father, I shall do you proud."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"As the priests say, first to your god, then to your king, then to your commander. Go therefore to the Abbey of Brigit's Light, then to the duties they have for our forces. Return home when you can, for I would like much to hear news of your travels. Dismissed."

TEXT.English: Your confessor approaches you as you prepare your army to move. "Commander Decius, we have uncovered the source of the taint we discovered in the jungles. In fact, it stems from the ports of the Lanun. We had negotiated trade relations with the Lanun, but apparently they have allowed their cities to be infested by the Overlords. We must wipe out every city with the Octopus Overlords religion."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rosier says "So you only freed the twisted men in order to track them down and destroy them?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"If these people have given their souls to demons, their lives are forfeit. If their Oaths hold true, they shall dwell with Junil forever. Either way we shall protect the Bannor from this taint, and the power of the good shall not fade nor flicker from the face of Erebus."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This seems less of good than of power to me, Decius." says Rosier.

TEXT.English: A Speaker is brought before you as you watch the destruction of the Lanun's Temple of the Overlords. "Your trespass here is unforgivable! This sacred ground rings with echoes of the depths."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Your allegiance to evil has sealed your fate," Wallon says.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Fate is ours to twist, and vengeance mine to take. Rise, servants!"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius scans the horizon, then shouts to his advisors, "Look to the horizon! Drown rise from the depths and head for Cuantine. We cannot get there before them on foot."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rosier says "The artifacts of these cultists, I have seen them used to travel over the water."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We cannot risk the taint these bear," the Confessor tells him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Foolish priest, it is worth the risk. You gamble the lives of our people for your purity's sake? You follow your law, then, and I will follow my own heart." Rosier dons the mask of the Speaker, and heads towards the waves.

TEXT.English: There is a lair ahead, a dwelling of barbarians that will menace civilized lands until defeated. But this one is guarded by a Barbarian Hero. Confessor Wallon speaks, "Our forces seem reluctant to fight, despite my exhortations. I bid thee research Orders from Heaven, that we might make use of the Oath-taker Heroes. In fact, I find your tardiness to study the will of Junil disappointing, but that is a matter for another time. Heroes such as Rosier will grow more powerful with time, so you can wait until this battle is to our advantage."

TEXT.English: The Confessor walks among the ruins of the lair. "This is surely the taint Junil has warned us of. We must eliminate the camp and everyone in it."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rosier is reluctant to follow his command. "Many of these twisted men were slaves and captives. By what right do we put them to the sword?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The Bannor Empire is the sole beacon of hope for this world. Should we allow taint to spread this close to the heart of the Empire?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We should trust our god enough to let innocent men return to their homes."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]" ...Perhaps you are right. Very well, Commander Decius, should they give their Oath to Rosier, I will permit them return to their homes. Then we should return to the Abbey."

TEXT.English: During the Age of Magic Kylorin used magical trials to separate common mages from the truly talented. The things that appeared in the trials were illusions, but the risk of death was real. Most died, but the few that passed the trials went on to be some of the most powerful archmages of their age.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some or the leaders in the current age, such as Os-Gabella and Perpentach, went through these trials when Patria was still the only empire of man. Others, such as Laroth, Barbatos or Trenton Majosi are less well known survivors of the trials.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It was hundreds of years into the Age of Rebirth before Dain of the Amurites, discovered the records of these magical trials. They were considered archaic, a violent reminder of Patria during its darkest hours. The culture of the Amurites celebrated public study of magic and this was seen as a more enlightened approach.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But Dain wondered how he compared to the Patrian archmages. And was even more interested in the greater talent the trial seemed to imbue in the lucky few who survived. Dain searched for, and found several locations for these trials, but most were simply empty towers, dungeons or cave labyrinths. Until in the year 441 of the fourth age Dain found the location of one that was still active.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The locals, a group of Balseraph fishermen living on the edge of their empire, long ago learned to avoid the cave; no one who entered it ever came out. They claimed death himself lived within it. They also claimed that chickens were divine, so Dain didnt take their warnings very seriously.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With a spellstaff and healing salve ready, as these were the traditional aides given to those taking the trial, Dain entered the cave.

They also claimed that chickens were divine, so Dain didnt take their warnings very seriously.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With a spellstaff and healing salve ready, as these were the traditional aides given to those taking the trial, Dain entered the cave.
TEXT.Spanish: During the Age of Magic Kylorin used magical trials to separate common mages from the truly talented. The things that appeared in the trials were illusions, but the risk of death was real. Most died, but the few that passed the trials went on to be some of the most powerful archmages of their age.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some or the leaders in the current age, such as Os-Gabella and Perpentach, went through these trials when Patria was still the only empire of man. Others, such as Laroth, Barbatos or Trenton Majosi are less well known survivors of the trials.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It was hundreds of years into the Age of Rebirth before Dain of the Amurites, discovered the records of these magical trials. They were considered archaic, a violent reminder of Patria during its darkest hours. The culture of the Amurites celebrated public study of magic and this was seen as a more enlightened approach.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But Dain wondered how he compared to the Patrian archmages. And was even more interested in the greater talent the trial seemed to imbue in the lucky few who survived. Dain searched for, and found several locations for these trials, but most were simply empty towers, dungeons or cave labyrinths. Until in the year 441 of the fourth age Dain found the location of one that was still active.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The locals, a group of Balseraph fishermen living on the edge of their empire, long ago learned to avoid the cave; no one who entered it ever came out. They claimed death himself lived within it. They also claimed that chickens were divine, so Dain didnt take their warnings very seriously.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With a spellstaff and healing salve ready, as these were the traditional aides given to those taking the trial, Dain entered the cave.

TEXT.English: Fireball- Summons a ball of fire which the caster can hurl at enemies from 2 plots away, farther if the caster has extension promotions. Fireball does fire damage to the enemy unit it strikes and some collateral damager to other units in the stack. Note that a lot of creatures, including most demons and orcs have some fire resistance, making this spell less effective against them. But some units, such as the Drown and Wood Golems are vulnerable to fire damage and take additional damage form fireballs.

Ein Feuerball verursacht Schaden durch Verbrennung bei einer feindlichen Einheit, die er trifft, und leichte Kollateralschäden bei den anderen Einheiten eines Einheitenverbandes. Erwähnenswert ist, dass viele Kreaturen, einschließlich der meisten Dämonen und Orks, Feuer widerstehen können, wodurch dieser Zauber gegen sie weniger wirkungsvoll ist. Aber manche Einheiten, wie Ertränkte und Holzgolems, sind durch Feuer verwundbarer und nehmen durch Feuerbälle zusätzlichen Schaden.

TEXT.English: Maelstrom- Does lightning damage to all units within 2 tiles. Be careful with it as it doesn't distinguish between enemy, neutral and friendly units and it will be treated as a declaration of war if you damage another players units with it. Maelstrom can't reduce a unit below 50% damage, so its best used to weaken enemy units before sending your warriors in to do battle.

Daher wird jeder Schaden an einer fremden Einheit, der durch den Zauber verursacht wird, als Kriegserklärung gewertet. Ein Mahlstrom kann die Lebenspunkte einer Einheit nicht unter 50% senken und wird deshalb am besten eingesetzt, um feindliche Einheiten zu schwächen, bevor die eigentlichen Krieger in den Kampf geschickt werden.

TEXT.English: Raise Skeleton- Allows you to summon a skeleton to serve you. The skeleton will last until it is killed, but as long as it exists the caster won't be able to summon any more. Skeleton can learn promotions and level up but their low strength keeps them from being that threatening. Also some of their strength comes from Death magic, which isn't used against units like Golems, Demons and other Undead.

TEXT.German: Skelett erschaffen: Erlaubt Euch, ein Skelett zu beschwören, das Euch dient. Ein Skelett wird bestehen bleiben, bis es besiegt wird. Allerdings kann der Zaubernde, solange es existiert, keine weiteren Skelette beschwören. Ein Skelett kann Beförderungen und Stufenaufstieg erlangen, aber seine geringe Stärke lässt es nicht gerade besonders bedrohlich wirken. Außerdem bezieht es einen Teil seiner Stärke aus der Todesmagie, die auf Einheiten wie Golems, Dämonen und andere Untote keine Auswirkungen hat.

TEXT.English: Three years after Dain successfully passed the trial he had a Cave of Ancestors built in Cevedes. Although some still died in the trials the study of the Amurites served them well in preparing mages before they entered. The trial was always open, but never required, for any mages to enter. And some did go through before they were ready to tragic results. But outside of those mistakes it continues to be a legacy of Patria and cornerstone of Amurite tradition.

TEXT.English: Giant spiders are invisible to all but recon units. They lay in wait in forested areas and attack units that draw to close to them. Sometimes wild giant spiders or captured ones will produce baby spiders after kills. These can grow to giant spiders after feeding.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Giant spiders are poisonous and will poison units that defeat them in combat. To get rid of this effect have your units healed by a priest or if your unit starts the turn completely healed the poison will wear off.

Diese können durch Fütterung zu Riesenspinnen heranwachsen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Riesenspinnen sind giftig und vergiften deshalb Einheiten, die eine Riesenspinne im Kampf besiegen. Um diesen Effekt zu kurieren, muss eine Einheit von einem Priester geheilt werden. Oder die Vergiftung verschwindet, falls eine Einheit die Runde vollständig geheilt beginnt.

TEXT.English: "Falamar..." Chaeli whispered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He pushed her against one of the massive crates that littered the docks of Dunwich. The moon was well past its zenith and the narrow gap between two crates where they found themselves was hidden in shadows. It was a beautiful night, but the stink of the docks hung thick in the air.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She leaned back as his kisses wandered down her neck to her very ample bosom. Only stopping when she playfully pulled his hands away when they reached inside her bodice.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain't ya ever wanted to be with the legendary Falamar?" he asked and she smiled radiantly, letting him grope her until he began pulling up on her dress.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, no," she said, "just kiss me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There was a second of anger in his eyes, even in her drunken haze Chaeli recognized it, she had seen it before from other men and it never ended well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He kissed her again, raising her hands above her head where he held both with one of his hands. He held them so tightly they felt like they were manacled to the wall. His other hand reached down and pulled up her dress, tearing it aside and reaching hungrily into it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"No, Falamar," she yelled. Then when he wouldn't stop she bit his cheek.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]He let go of his dress and punched her full in the face, her head crunched against the wooden crate and seagulls along the dock yelled in complaint and took to flight. She started crying as he reached again for her dress.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Did someone call me?" A man standing a the edge of the crates asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The attacker, the man pretending to be Falamar, quickly let go of Chaeli and stepped away from the speaker. The speaker was a thin handsome man, lean and confident though he looked dangerous now, like a coiled snake. Though Chaeli felt unthreatened by him, her attacker felt differently and he immediately let go of Chaeli.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Captain Falamar," he stammered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Issac?" Falamar answered, "I was sure I heard my name."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar, the real Falamar, kept advancing into the makeshift alley between the crates and Issac kept backing up. When Falamar reached Chaeli he asked her, "Are you okay?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She nodded and tried to wipe the tears from her eyes. She could already feel her face bruising up from the punch.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I'm sorry Falamar," Issac said, "sometimes I tell the gullie's I'm you. Just a bit of wishful dreaming I suppose."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"That is not the crime I am concerned about." Falamar answered. Then Falamar struck, jumping forward he caught the larger man by the collar and slammed him back against the crates. Issac drew his knife but Falamar knocked it easily aside. With Issac trapped against the crate Falamar punched him, splintering Issac's cheekbone so severely it left his left eye rolling loosely in its socket and his cheek ran flush with purple blood.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Go or I will give my sword to the lady and she will act out her desires on you, as you had intended for her."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Issac scrambled away.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chaeli, stunned into silence until this moment, fell suddenly into uncontrollable tears. Falamar tilted up her face, checking her bruise and as her sobs quieted her gave her a slight smile.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Can I walk you home?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chaeli only nodded in response. They walked in silence through the empty streets. Despite the trauma it was still a beautiful night and as they approached the squat flat Chaeli shared with her family she finally spoke.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I thought... he said he was you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar waited until they stood before her door before he answered.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You deserve better than the Dunwich docks. Expect more from men, no matter their name."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She nodded, not really understanding.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Will you be okay?" Falamar asked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes, my father is home. I will be okay, thanks to you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Falamar gave her another slight smile, said good night and headed back toward the docks. They were supposed to have set sail hours ago but Falamar was late as usual. He arrived to find the ship and the crew ready. Several men traded knowing glances as he came aboard.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"What was her name this time captain?" one called.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I didn't ask." Falamar responded.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]His men laughed and cheered, they all assumed incorrectly but it boosted their spirits and Falamar saw little harm in it. The legend was certainly greater than the man, but when you regularly asked your men to face death sometimes it was easier if they believed a legend led them.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Amergin, Falamar's first mate, had already loaded the supplies and made sure the crew was on board and relatively sober. He had questions but had been serving Falamar since they were both boys, so he knew he would get the answers when Falamar was ready.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes Amergin, we will be sailing out by moonlight. I have a contract from a Balseraph princess and it seems we need to make up some time. She pays well, and needs us to trap some animals for her."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Its an unusual task for you," Amergin commented.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Easy gold and a damsel who needs help. It sounds exactly like me."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Amergin smiled and ordered the crew to lift the anchor and set sail. Within seconds the ship was off to the Aegis Isles.

TEXT.English: Keelyn giggles gleefully at the caged animals and construction of the upcoming Grand Menagerie. "This is wonderful," she squeals, "fetch me one of those big grey teethy beasts!"

TEXT.English: Keelyn stares in amazement at the captured elephant. "I've heard of another pet, a chicken cat. Get one of those for me too!"

TEXT.English: She was a delightful, if not demented, child and she twirled and danced between the animals we had assembled for her. Her courtier counted out the gold we had been promised and excused her behavior, though it was his disdain for her that bothered me far more than the young princess's enthusiasm.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After checking each animal Keelyn approached me. She had a griffon feather in her hair and her dress, though once beautiful, was now patched and worn as if unable to keep up with the tiny tornado.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"These must be the most excellent animals from anywhere on Erebus!"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I smiled, "I am pleased that you think so, my hunters searched every corner of this island to find them for you. Where other princesses have rooms of toy animals, you will have the real things."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She grinned. This was my plan, to keep her focused on how wonderful it was. Her mind didn't dwell long on achievements and she was usually racing off to the next goal, and I had tired of searching this island for whatever she wanted next. But it was too late, her smile faded and her brow furrowed in thought. She was going to ask for more.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It is a wonderful collection, but what about those that don't live on the island? What about those in the sea? The Lanun are talented fishermen, right?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The best," I answered, at least this was the sort of hunting my men would prefer, "would you like us to gather some giant crabs, otolochs, or tortoises for you?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She seemed to consider the suggestion, "No" she said, "do you know the giant wiggly beasts that are painted on the walls of the temple in Shaol?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Yes, squids. They wouldn't survive long in your zoo I'm afraid. They had to stay in the water."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Keelyn nodded, "Bring me some and I'll have Chuckles close in the harbor so they can't run away."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Occasionally we caught squid in our nets, from those as long as a man's arm to those twice as long as a man. It wouldn't be much trouble to snare a few for her.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Of course," I said loud enough for her snobbish courtier to hear, "we would be happy to capture a few squid for your collection, for the same price as the others."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The courtier sighed and looked as disappointed as Keelyn was excited.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Load up the ships," I called to the men, "we do the rest of our hunting from beneath the white and purple, and atop a hull full of rum."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]My men cheered and a few hours later we set out from the docks with a fair wind and high spirits.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I dropped into darkness. I could hear the explosion of splintering wood and sense the movement of a giant around me. Something so great even the whales feared it. The central mast broke and plunged past me through the water. This was the only indication I had of direction, and I began swimming desperately toward the direction the mast came from.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The seas were rough, but the Lanun like to say that just requires more drink to steady the ship. Though it was the perfect area for fishing our nets came up empty on every pull. We were preparing to move back towards the coast when the creatures attacked.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Giant tentacles reached up over the deck and crushed the ships as if they were made of paper. There was no coherent defense against this attack and the screaming of my men disappeared as the sea claimed me.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Just as I saw the shimmer of light through the inky darkness, as my lungs burned for air, I felt the tip of a tentacle close around my leg. I reached for my sword, but the sheath was empty. I had lost it in the water. A tug pulled me down, away from that golden halo of light and I fought for any way out of its grip.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There was a single glint of metal in the darkness. It floated down from the remains of the ship and I reached to catch it. It was beyond my reach so I twisted against the tentacle, buying myself a precious few inches and I closed my hand around it. I immediately twisted back into the tentacle bringing the weapon to cut it from my leg. Only to discover that I only held a silver candlestick. In that moment my lungs exploded and I drank in the sea. All else disappeared.

TEXT.English: Flauros looks up as Decius and his troops enter the palace. "Ah, commander, how go our plans?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius crosses his arms. "I've tried things your way. This Empyrean religion is only gaining followers. It is time to be more aggressive."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have discussed why that is not among your options."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This Varn Gosam has called a meeting of tribal leaders. My spies tell me they are leaning toward uniting with him. Your foes will hold much more power in this region unless we act to stop them. I will take your army to the Malakim capital and burn it to the ground. That should keep the sand rats in their place."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You will act within the limits I have set for you. Or I will tear you to shreds."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius raised blade. "Can you do so before I get in a single hit?" Flauros laughed, drawing his own blade, but Decius continued, "Because the Council's assassins have shown me a few things. Such as a rare desert plant, the extracts of which can cause a man pain like he's never known for as long as he lives. Perhaps you are willing to chance that over the course of your very long life you can find an antidote. Or that the effects will wear off after only a few hundred years. But why not chance that your power can be used beyond playing shepherd to a broken people, can rather shape the world stage to our benefit?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros stood a moment, gazing at Decius. Then he sheathed his blade. "My sister would have killed you, and lived with the pain. Very well, take what you need. Raze every city with the Empyrean. If you bring calamity upon us, I will survive, and you will not, no matter the trump you hold. If your gamble succeeds, you will have a place among us forever."

TEXT.English: The primitive encampment of the Hill Giants is razed, and the Giants themselves feeding the vultures. In one hut dwell a score of human slaves, their eyes lighting up at the sight of the destruction of their captors. One young man in tattered yellow clothes approaches Decius. "In the name of Lugus the Light, I thank you sir."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Who is this Lugus? Your feudal lord?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Nay, good sir, he is the god of light, whose wisdom enlightens all the peoples of this desert."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius yanks the mans chains, pulling him to his knees. "Not wise enough to keep you safe, nor alert you when you speak to a foe." [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros is pleased to see that Decius has the mettle he suspected. Less so to hear of the Ecclesiastic. "I have not seen a priest of Lugus for over six hundred years, and now one appears on my borders? This is an ill sign."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius raises an eyebrow. "Six hundred years? The Prelates spoke of devil-men living in the desert of Myrh. I hadn't expected they were being quite so literal."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have no allegiance to Hell, simply similar tactics-extracting power from mortals. I trust this doesn't strain our working arrangement?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius shrugged. "I've little illusions about how you treat your subjects. What you do with their souls is even less my concern. I've passed your test. What is next?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The Bannor were fools to discard such a useful tool as you. Efficient and heartless. But I need guile as well. Lugus is an old foe, and not one to release a grudge. His cult gaining ground here means trouble for us. I need you to strike down these Ecclesiastics, without drawing us into direct confrontation with the desert tribes."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I've seen your power. Give me command of a larger force of vampires and we can be ruling this entire desert."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have shared our secret with you, Decius, but wish it to remain that. If we take ourselves into the battlefield, we will be hunted down by all the nations. Better to stay on the edges of the civilized world. Lugus has other enemies that may aid us, however, without asking questions. Let us encourage the Council of Esus among our lands, and train men who can strike without revealing their masters. Use them to eliminate the disciples of Lugus, and the power I wield may be yours."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Very well, we will do this your way, Flauros."

I hadn't expected they were being quite so literal."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have no allegiance to Hell, simply similar tactics-extracting power from mortals. I trust this doesn't strain our working arrangement?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius shrugged. "I've little illusions about how you treat your subjects. What you do with their souls is even less my concern. I've passed your test. What is next?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"The Bannor were fools to discard such a useful tool as you. Efficient and heartless. But I need guile as well. Lugus is an old foe, and not one to release a grudge. His cult gaining ground here means trouble for us. I need you to strike down these Ecclesiastics, without drawing us into direct confrontation with the desert tribes."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I've seen your power. Give me command of a larger force of vampires and we can be ruling this entire desert."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I have shared our secret with you, Decius, but wish it to remain that. If we take ourselves into the battlefield, we will be hunted down by all the nations. Better to stay on the edges of the civilized world. Lugus has other enemies that may aid us, however, without asking questions. Let us encourage the Council of Esus among our lands, and train men who can strike without revealing their masters. Use them to eliminate the disciples of Lugus, and the power I wield may be yours."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Very well, we will do this your way, Flauros."

TEXT.English: An obese, pale man, carried on a litter by a slaves watches Decius training his units for the assault on Dirage. Decius walks over after organizing a scout patrol. "I don't suppose you've come to enlist," he says. The man has the clear signs of Calabim aristocracy, but Decius takes a measure of satisfaction from refusing to acknowledge it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I am the governor of this city. Flauros decrees that I must cooperate with you, find out what you need to research for your task. It pleases him to give this authority to such as yourself, for reasons I couldn't grasp."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius thought for a moment. "If I am successful, I will have the cusp of an empire. Feudalism would be useful for this, though..." He glanced up at the governor, realizing he wanted more than to build an empire for lazy fools like these. Deception. Poison. Tools like these could help him in a conflict with his benefactor Flauros or other foes to come. Religion was a useful tool for controlling a nation, but he decided it would be a poor idea to invite such foreign influence and invite the eye of meddling goods.

TEXT.English: Decius has fled the Bannor, seeking refuge across the sea. In the desert of Myrh dwell the Malakim, a morally upright people. He has had his fill of moral presumption, however, and seeks shelter amongst a more ethically flexible culture.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Calabim are an ancient order whose aristocracy prey on the weak of their society. Weakness has long since been drilled out of Decius.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It is a blighted neighborhood on the outskirts of Prespur over which Decius has exerted influence. Between the battered humans who have had their wills broken and those petty thugs just strong enough to prey on them, he has no competition for the petty fiefdom he sets up, so long as the aristocrats do not deign to enter.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros, second born of all vampires, has seen this play out many times before. It is a replay of the Calabim social structure on a smaller scale, and he delights in letting the local lord know who is really on top.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius knows he is playing a dangerous game. When the bloodpets of the Vampiric lord come, his army is alert and dispatches them promptly. Flauros himself, however, is harder to handle. He personally slays Decius's army of exiles and criminals, leaving the bodies for the Moroi. Decius himself is far too interesting to do in, however.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"We have few immigrants here, and fewer still with your skills. Why do you come to our land, only to wallow in the filth of the livestock?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius folds his arms. "I kept every code and rule of my home, only to have them turn me out. I am through with rules and submission to authority. I will rise to the top, or die on my feet."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Flauros smiled. "Whether you know it or not, you have come to the right place then. Our nation is a meritocracy in ways the Bannor would never hope to emulate. Those undeserving are consumed, while those who prove themselves are rewarded beyond their keen. I offer you a chance to start down this path. I will give you command of a small force. Eliminate the Hill Giants that have been preying on our countryside."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius nodded. "Very well. But with the rabble you call soldiers, I don't give good odds of my survival."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Either way it will be entertaining."

TEXT.English: Decius earned a place among the Calabim through grit and guile, and has forced them to take a more competitive place among the nations of Erebus. Just as a competition is heating up on the other side of the desert of Myrh. Word comes through the Undercouncil of dark plans reaching fulfillment, as the Sheaim complete their masterstroke and unleash the Infernals into the world. This is not as the Calabim would have preferred, but does present opportunities. Flauros offers Decius the opportunity to see how best he can exploit this brutal war. The remnants of the Malakim have taken arms in defense of their friends, so Decius sets out in a fleet of ships to flank them on the foothills of Tempus Mor.

TEXT.English: Varn was a difficult man to find in the weeks after his revelations. Decius came upon him sending out a group of messengers, and he turned to Decius to explain, "We can no longer tarry with the tribes of this desert. I will call a council meeting. A desert custom I hope to incorporate into the Overcouncil. Those that adopted our faith will join with us, but I fear we will alienate those that did not. Either way, your task has not changed, just expanded. You need to spread this faith throughout the region. It must become the dominant creed here for our alliance to last. TEXT.English: Decius has fled his homeland after being charged with witchcraft and conjuring demons. He seeks to preserve his values and find a new beginning among the Malakim, across the seas in the desert of Myrh. This ancient tribal people is coalescing around an unlikely new spiritual leader-the elf Varn Gosam, a refugee from an isolated elven community.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Malakim have taken in Decius and his entourage; hospitality in the desert is an iron law. He has yet to see meet his host, however.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While watching the young soldiers drill in the evening Decius is approached by a raven-haired woman flanked by a sand lion cub. Flowing robes keep the sun off her skin but do nothing to hide her figure as the wind blows them taut against her. "Welcome, stranger. You have the look of one who well knows the art these boys struggle to master."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I was a soldier of some renown, milady, and a commander for a season. I felled my people's enemies, until I was deemed one."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Strong and wise, and bereft of your heritage, like our Varn. We could make use of your skills, in exchange for a place of refuge."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"A gracious offer, milady. Have you the authority to make it?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"It is not authority I wield here, just influence, but I suspect it will be enough. More so if you could perform one task for us now. Varn Gosam has been gone for some time on pilgrimage, too long I fear. Lead a party to find him, east at the Mirror of Heaven, and you will have proven your worth and earned your place."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius rises with a nod. "I shall do so then. Who shall I say has commissioned this search?'[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The lady smiles. "My name is Talia."

TEXT.English: The windswept dunes change gradually as Decius nears the holy site of the Malakim. Travel across the flat glass field is treacherous, but in the center, near a crystal clear pool is Varn Gosam. Amidst a warm glow, he stands and greets the stern man leading the Malakim soldiers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"You must be Decius. I came here to seek further guidance from Lugus the Light, who led me from the Shadowed Vale in preparation for some task. It is good to see that the Malakim have taken you in, as they have me. They are a hospitable people, with a destiny far beyond the dunes. I have no doubt you can find your purpose among them."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius turned his eyes from the glowing water. "The Bannor's priesthood gave me a clear purpose as well, to fight evil and stamp out heresy. I served them well and was betrayed. I think for a time I am content with aimlessness."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Varn smiled. "This is a new day for you, Decius. Dawn comes, and it is no time for slumber. For any who love good and freedom, for Lugus has shown me a vision of evil stirring in a far-off land. We must prepare, must bind together all good peoples in one council house before it is too late. Will you help me spread this vision? First to our brethren tribes in this desert, and beyond, to the peoples of the Elohim, the Kuriotates, the Khazad, the Ljosalfar-and perhaps even to the Bannor as well?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I cannot turn on my ideals. If it is as you say, I will serve you and your cause, Gosam. Even if it means facing those who wrongly seek my head."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And in return, you will never need do so alone. This is the message of the Empyrean." Varn Gosam loaded his belongings-incense, a water skin, a light tent, a pouch of salted meat-onto his camel. His tone changed as he and Decius headed back towards the awaiting Malakim party. "Lugus spoke to me of one other thing, Decius. The people to our East have a dread secret, and an ancient grudge with our good god. As we seek to spread our faith, I fear they will be an implacable foe, opposing us with sword and spell."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This kind of opposition I am well suited for dealing with, Varn. Prepare your teachers, and I will guard them with our soldiers."

They are a hospitable people, with a destiny far beyond the dunes. I have no doubt you can find your purpose among them."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Decius turned his eyes from the glowing water. "The Bannor's priesthood gave me a clear purpose as well, to fight evil and stamp out heresy. I served them well and was betrayed. I think for a time I am content with aimlessness."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Varn smiled. "This is a new day for you, Decius. Dawn comes, and it is no time for slumber. For any who love good and freedom, for Lugus has shown me a vision of evil stirring in a far-off land. We must prepare, must bind together all good peoples in one council house before it is too late. Will you help me spread this vision? First to our brethren tribes in this desert, and beyond, to the peoples of the Elohim, the Kuriotates, the Khazad, the Ljosalfar-and perhaps even to the Bannor as well?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I cannot turn on my ideals. If it is as you say, I will serve you and your cause, Gosam. Even if it means facing those who wrongly seek my head."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"And in return, you will never need do so alone. This is the message of the Empyrean." Varn Gosam loaded his belongings-incense, a water skin, a light tent, a pouch of salted meat-onto his camel. His tone changed as he and Decius headed back towards the awaiting Malakim party. "Lugus spoke to me of one other thing, Decius. The people to our East have a dread secret, and an ancient grudge with our good god. As we seek to spread our faith, I fear they will be an implacable foe, opposing us with sword and spell."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"This kind of opposition I am well suited for dealing with, Varn. Prepare your teachers, and I will guard them with our soldiers."

TEXT.English: Decius has found a new home with the Malakim, and now leads Varn Gosam's quest to unite the good nations under an Overcouncil, to fight the prophesied resurgence of an ancient foe.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]But their success in the desert of Myrh is about to be tested. Messengers arrive from the Elohim, imploring their allies to come to their aid. The Sheaim, a secretive tribe west of the Elohim homelands, have uncovered a dark ritual, bringing the Archangel of Agares, Hyborem, into Erebus. He has emerged in the mountains of Tempus Mor leading an army of Infernals; from further west come tales of more demonic invasions. At the same time the Svartalfar have taken advantage of the situation to declare war on their rivals, restarting the elven war that had concluded when one queen perished years ago. Ethne the White warns that she is considering desperate action to preserve her people, and so Varn Gosam requests Decius bring the armies of the Malakim west, in an attempt to preserve the alliance of the Overcouncil and bring peace to Tempus Mor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Though once betrayed by the Bannor, the skills they taught him will be put to the test.

TEXT.English: Lord of the Balors
TEXT.French: Seigneur des Balors
TEXT.German: Fürst der Balor
TEXT.Italian: Lord of the Balors
TEXT.Spanish: Lord of the Balors

TEXT.English: During the Age of Ice men made sacrifices here in order to appease what they believed to be the gods beyond. In a world of permanent winter the burning lands beyond seemed like a twisted heaven to the primitive men of that age. But these "gods" demanded sacrifices from their worshippers that were often more costly than the cold.

But these "gods" demanded sacrifices from their worshippers that were often more costly than the cold.
TEXT.German: Während des Zeitalters des Eises brachten die Menschen hier Opfer dar, um jene zu besänftigen, die sie für die jenseitigen Götter hielten. In einer Welt des permanenten Winters erschienen die brennenden Lande des Jenseits den primitiven Menschen dieses Zeitalters wie eine verdrehte Version des Himmels. Aber diese "Götter" forderten Opfergaben von ihren Gläubigen, die oft kostspieliger als die Kälte waren.

TEXT.English: This altar is for the Lord of the Balors. The vast minions of hell sacrifice here in the hope of gaining some favor with Hyborem. Many generals have made it this far, but you are the first that wasnt carried here by demonic legions and sacrificed on the black and red stone.

TEXT.German: Dieser Altar ist dem Meister der Balor geweiht. Die vielen Lakaien der Hölle bringen hier ihre Opfer in der Hoffnung dar, eine kleine Gunst von Hyborem zu erhalten. Viele Generäle haben es bis hier geschafft, aber Ihr seid der erste, der nicht von den dämonischen Legionen hierher getragen und auf dem schwarz-roten Stein geopfert wurde.

TEXT.English: The Balseraphs stared at the distant city of Dis, more terrifying than anything even their fertile imaginations could have created. The pass is covered in dark monuments to Hyborem's countless achievements. The corpses of his foes are built into these monuments or scattered across the wastes as a warning to any who would seek to defeat him. The stenches of sulfur and rotting flesh mingle together, making the foulest slums of Jubilee seem like a paradise. And the dread metropolis of Dis itself rises above it all. None of the Balseraphs dare imagine how many damned souls toil in that wretched city, or how many of them are armed and ready to defend it, rather than risk displeasing their dread masters.[PARAGRAPH:1]"It smells funny," Keelyn says, "but it could be pretty with a new coat of paint. I'm thinking pink. Everything looks nicer in pink."

TEXT.German: Die Balseraph starrten auf die ferne Stadt Dis, die Furcht einflößender war, als sie es sich selbst mit ihrer lebhaften Vorstellungskraft hätten ausmalen können. Der Pass ist gespickt mit dunklen Monumenten für Hyborems zahllosen Taten. Die Leichen seiner Feinde sind in diese Monumente eingelassen oder über die Einöde verstreut, als Warnung für jene, die versuchen sollten, ihn zu besiegen. Der Gestank von Schwefel und verrotendem Fleisch vermischen sich und lassen den dreckigsten Slum von Jubilee wie ein Paradies erscheinen. Und die grauenvolle Metropole Dis selbst thront über allem. Keiner der Balseraph wagt sich auch nur vorzustellen, wieviele verdammte Seelen in dieser elenden Stadt gequält werden, oder wieviele davon bewaffnet und lieber bereit sind, sie zu verteidigen, als die Verärgerung ihrer Meister zu riskieren.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Es riecht komisch", sagt Keelyn, "aber es könnte mit einem neuen Anstrich ganz hübsch sein. Ich denke an Rosa. Alles sieht in Rosa schöner aus."

TEXT.English: The Mercurian men cheered. These were fierce, passionate men who viewed their lives as a temporary stage before their transform into the magnificent angels of Basiums army. They threw themselves fully into battle and marched unquestioning into the Fane of Lessers. Death in righteous battle was their hope. There was no such thing as an old Mercurian soldier.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The angels were more somber. The Seraphim with their blazing swords kept careful watch for more dangers, the Ophanim floated above the broken fields for the first time riding unhindered within the Fane and the Valkyries tended to the dead.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Basium stood before the Throne of Hell, a vast gaping hole in Erebus. The ground around it bled a thick, dark ichor. It was a physical wound in this world, fully contaminated and defiled. Through it hell could be seen, a vast mountain sloping ever down to dark swamps. Somewhere beyond that swamp Basium knew the foul city of Mammon sat. It was the first step in turning the souls of men into demons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Basium raised his club, within it demons howled in pain and torment, for it wouldnt let any demon it killed return to their immortal realms. Two Seraphim settled beside the portal, swords drawn.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Factum est." the Seraphim intoned.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Not yet" Basium replied, "our battle is not done. If we mean to truly defeat the Infernal we must tear down the city of Mammon, march across the fields of Camulos and destroy the temples of Aeron. Then we will rouse Agares himself, send an army into the dust sea and remove him from his dominion."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With that Basium marched through the gate and his army marched unquestioningly after him. After they had all passed through they destroyed the gate behind them. An entire army, a nation, walked willingly into hell and disappeared from Erebus.

TEXT.English: They had struck deeper into the Fane than any human army ever had. They had allies to watch their back, to guard the other passes. Brave Malakim champions, Balseraph mimics unpredictable but strangely reliable, and of course the heavenly armies of the Mercurians, giving grudging respect to their comrades. But the Bannor were ever at the vanguard. It was what they lived for. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Not one among this army had seen the fires of hell before, save the Commander. Those men and women who had crossed from that wretched land into world of Erebus were a dying generation. But the story of their journey survived in tales every young Bannor boy and girl learned, learned well and knew better than to doubt in the presence of their elders. The fierce dedication that had seen these people through constant war held them still enthralled, as well. This history and national character came together, leaving the Bannor knights, crusaders, and priests unflinching as they marched though the Fane, unrelenting, until even the terrible arch-angel Hyborem was overthrown. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria surveyed the ruins of Dis, the sprawling city Hyborem had ruled. Its dungeons were labyrinthine, and its streets filled with fiendish traps. Vile sights met the Bannor at every turn, men crucified and impaled, hanging from towers and buried up to their necks. It would be long and grim work razing the city while sanctifying those souls trapped here. But it brought some satisfaction to dismantle the apparatus of Hell on earth.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]They had not found what she came to find, but what they had accomplished was monumental, world changing. Surely more important than a personal quest to repay a priceless debt. She sighed and turned the corner, bringing the palace into view, the last refuge of the Fane. It had been pummeled by Bannor catapults, but in the ruins sat a wavering portal. The mages that accompanied her set about closing it, when from the rubble a group of hell hounds charged towards them. Capria threw herself in the way of the mages, buying time for them to get to cover. She braced for impact behind her shield, but the hound was felled from behind by a hurled spear. The other hounds rushed past her, fleeing, not attacking. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Capria lowered her shield and gasped as she saw who it was, even as she had hoped to find him. Donal Lugh, a fabled Bannor hero. Everyone who emerged from Hell all those years ago was a hero, but they all remembered the one who stayed behind, allowing them to escape with their savior Sabathiel to guide them. His hair and beard had grayed, but it was undeniably him. "Donal... I came to find you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Donal clasped the old woman, steadying her. "Aye, little one. And I thank you for it. Surviving hell was one thing took everything I had. Emerging here, in the Infernals' strongest outpost on Erebus almost made me lose hope. Until I heard that this place was under assault. I knew my people had come to finish things, to pay the demons back for what they took."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I never got to thank you. We need you back, old friend. We have lost Sabathiel. So many have lost their way, seeking power over justice." [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Donal held her still, and the ancient warrior and leader quieted. "The next battle will come soon enough. I will be there. It is unending for us-that is why we were chosen. But we can take a rest. I think we've earned it." Behind them the portal closed with a crash, as the Bannor mages severed the Fane from Agares's vault.

His hair and beard had grayed, but it was undeniably him. "Donal... I came to find you."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Donal clasped the old woman, steadying her. "Aye, little one. And I thank you for it. Surviving hell was one thing took everything I had. Emerging here, in the Infernals' strongest outpost on Erebus almost made me lose hope. Until I heard that this place was under assault.
